Award.AwardTitle: WSC-Category 3: Sustainable Large-Scale Deployment of Perennial Biomass Energy Crops
Award.AbstractNarration:
Confronting concerns associated with domestic energy security and large-scale anthropogenic climate change are principal factors for continued pursuit of renewable energy in the United States. Yet, detrimental indirect and inadvertent consequences related to both climate and food security for first generation biofuels, illustrate a non-sustainable approach to current bioenergy production. Expansion of perennial biomass energy crops such as switchgrass and miscanthus on U.S. degraded and abandoned farmland may prove to be a viable alternative. However, land-use change associated with this expansion may have additional, direct effects on natural water resources that requires assessment prior to large-scale surface alteration to ensure long-term environmental sustainability. This project will integrate physical (i.e., coupled hydro-climatic modeling, using WRF 3.4 coupled to two different land surface models), agricultural (i.e., crop modeling, using EPIC and CENTURY crop models), and socioeconomic (i.e., economic modeling, using FASOMGHG and BEPAM models) elements to evaluate system resilience associated with expansion of perennial bioenergy crops on U.S. degraded and abandoned farmland. Geographically explicit maps depicting sustainable regional "hot-spots" of perennial biomass energy expansion will be developed. The research will quantify impacts on the local hydrologic cycle, including effects on soil and groundwater resources (e.g., change in water table depth), and associated climatic consequences to determine if expansion is feasible and sustainable over decadal timescales. Assessment of photosynthetic production of bioenergy crops will be undertaken and resulting modeled yields will be translated to quantify the fraction of U.S. liquid fuel consumption that could be offset. The research will also evaluate economic profitability of growing perennial biomass energy crops in identified "hot-spot" areas. Potential designs for extension of agricultural programs, such as the commodity reserve program, to promote growth of perennial biomass energy crops in identified regions, will also be examined.

By exploring bioenergy expansion through an integrated lens that incorporates physical, agricultural, and economic elements, this project will guide local to national level agencies making decisions regarding the feasibility of biomass-derived energy. The modeling tools will enable water and resource managers as well as farmers to recognize impacts and trade-offs of large-scale deployment of perennial biomass energy crops to make more informed decisions for water resource management. Thus, the project will promote decision-maker participation and expand opportunities for citizen engagement. The project will also enable participation, expand opportunities, and assist in the mentoring of underrepresented groups through a unique educational collaboration with a not-for-profit (K-12) public charter school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goal of the project was to develop geographically explicit regional ?hot-spots? of sustainable perennial (e.g., miscanthus and switchgrass) biomass energy expansion on U.S. abandoned and degraded farmland. Our aim, using a trans-disciplinary approach that combines physical (i.e., climate), agricultural (i.e., assessment of crop yield), and socioeconomic (i.e., economic valuation) elements, was to quantify the long-term sustainability of large-scale deployment of perennial biomass energy crops to inform science-based policy in guiding local to national level agencies making decisions vis-?-vis biomass derived energy. To accomplish this we utilized state-of-the-art tools that (i) account for the atmosphere?s interaction with the underlying land surface to assess the long-term environmental sustainability of land use change (LUC) to perennial bioenergy crops; (ii) calculated perennial biomass energy crop yield based on the climatic response of LUC to perennial bioenergy crop deployment; (iii) examined economic profitability of growing such crops in the identified areas to determine the fraction of biofuel supply that could meet current transportation needs. Finally, a recent citizen engagement deliberation ? the World Wide Views (WWViews) on Climate and Energy, held in 2015 in 75 nations across the world - provided an opportunity to examine how participants? opinions on climate and energy are affected by public deliberation and whether this varies across geographical location, gender, age, and other demographic characteristics. 

The key objectives outlined above have been met through peer-reviewed publication in top disciplinary and interdisciplinary journals and have been disseminated at national and international conferences and meetings. 

Key results advance the dialogue of biomass energy expansion on continental U.S. (CONUS) abandoned and degraded farmland in three key ways across biophysical, agricultural and socioeconomic dimensions:

  1. Our climate simulations demonstrate, with realistically varying deployment scenarios of bioenergy cropping systems, maximum near-surface cooling of up to 5?C during the growing season over portions of the central United States and significant soil moisture reduction over the western Great Plains upon LUC to perennial bioenergy crops. Including impacts associated with groundwater dynamics appears to moderate the overall effect on the hydro-climate system;
  2. Our ecosystem modeling simulations for the two candidate bioenergy crops considered combined with simulated climate output reflecting impacts associated with LUC to perennial bioenergy cropping systems were used to identify the viability of the cellulosic biofuel industry across CONUS. Our results indicate that planting over the most suitable marginal lands, to the east of the 100th meridian in CONUS with bioenergy crops (either miscanthus or switchgrass) would be able to meet the projected U.S. jet fuel demand for 2020-2040 at prices under $4.5 per gallon of gasoline equivalent.
  3. The WWViews analysis produced expected outcomes (e.g., increased concern about climate change and an upsurge in recognition that climate change is primarily human-caused) and unexpected outcomes (e.g., 48% of participants believed that new technologies could solve climate change in the pre-deliberation assessment and 64% in the post-deliberation assessment). Our results highlight the importance of regional geographies and policies on citizen understanding of issues associated with climate and energy. Our results illustrate the variability in citizen preference for climate change policy as a national priority, with citizenry from some countries insisting it should be while others insisting it should not be a national priority.
